comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Speaking of voting! I've been threatening (in my own mind) for some time to write a post for our NLI blog about [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia]'s ludicrously lyrical limerickbybeachcomber[s]. I did start one, but then he keeps producing better and better Limericks based on our photos, e.g. The SS Scotia Limerick! If any of you would care to nominate your favourites, it might help me choose which to use. You can find them all here!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] You know I hate to be a contrarian. I'm not convinced this is Doon Well. Have a look at the stone formation of the well itself. The stones at Doon Well are really neat, and surrounded by flat area of small stones (all the more painful to kneel on?). In this photo, the stones are far more rugged...

Would you like me to upload Doon Well here? The crutches, bandages, rosary beads are amazing!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Hmm. I guess the rock under the capstone on the right is different to the one in the Doon Well photo - much squarer. Maybe not Doon after all. Is there any likelihood that adjacent items in the catalogue are geographically close?

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Sure. Be nice to see better detail. Maybe I'm the contrarian..I agree stone setup different but there's a good few decades between images. L_ROY_09330 is unrecognisable today?? I could be wrong.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] There is a likelihood alright, though absolutely no guarantees. The one before is Church ruin, tower and some walls only, 2 people in foreground and the one after is Carts, etc on road with telegraph line through hills if anything there looks any way familiar...

comment._content: I'd go for "sad eyes" - that poor woman would have lived through the Famine and no doubt had plenty of people to be praying for at the well.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
From a lecture entitled "the Hiistory and Scene of some Pilgrimages in Donegal" given by the Very Rev. J. M'Devitt, as reported in Freeman's on Nov 29 1876
The Rev. Lecturer said a thick rain was falling when he drove late one evening last summer over the long and steep hill of Mcenaroy, near Letterkenny, in the county Donegal. Looking before him into the dim twilight he saw a figure moving forward with much difficulty. Soon he came up with a peasant carrying a parcel on his back, who told him he was returning from a pilgrimage to "Doon Well," with a few bottles of its miraculous water, and that his home was still distant thirty miles off, near those mighty cliffs on the western coast of the county beneath which the waves of the wild Atlantic rave and roar for ever. The peasant went on to talk with enthusiasm of the supernatural powers of his precious burden, while he listened, and fancied he heard in the wind the sneers of modern unbelievers, directed, however with harmless effect, against the strong faith of the humble pilgrim (applause).
But no mention of a scary-eyed woman, unfortunately.
